subject: Design
title: Greek Andron: Rooms That Defined Social Status
description: A 60-second lesson on Greek Andron: Rooms That Defined Social Status.

hook.text: In ancient Greece, the fanciest room in the house was reserved for men's dinner parties. Women were banned.

buildup.text: The andron had mosaic floors, painted walls, and reclining couches arranged for philosophical debate.

discovery.text: Interior design was a social tool: the andron's luxury displayed the host's wealth and intellect.

twist.text: Women's quarters (gynaikonitis) were plain and hidden upstairs â€” design enforcing social hierarchy.

climax.text: Greek homes prove that interior design has always been about power, status, and social control.

punchline.text: Rooms don't just contain life. They shape who gets to live it.

quiz.question: What was the andron in an ancient Greek home?
options: A luxurious room for male dinner parties
